penalty_ratedecimalPenalty rate for missed payments (optional, default 0)
statusstringLoan status: Active, Paid, Defaulted
created_atdatetimeTimestamp of creation
updated_atdatetimeTimestamp of the last update

LoanLines Model

This table tracks individual transactions (payments, penalties, or adjustments) related to a loan.

Column NameData TypeDescription
idbigintPrimary key
loan_idbigintForeign key linking to the loan
transaction_idbigintForeign key linking to the Transaction
entry_datedateDate of the entry
amountdecimalPayment or adjustment amount
typestringEntry type: Payment, Penalty, or Adjustment
descriptiontextNotes about the transaction
created_atdatetimeTimestamp of creation
updated_atdatetimeTimestamp of the last update

Interest Calculation

1. Flat Interest

  • Formula: Total Interest=Principal AmountInterest RateDuration (in years)\text{Total Interest} = \text{Principal Amount} \times \text{Interest Rate} \times \text{Duration (in years)}Total Interest=Principal AmountInterest RateDuration (in years)
  • Repayment Schedule: Equal installments covering principal and interest.

2. Reducing Balance Interest

  • Formula (Monthly): Interest Amount=Outstanding PrincipalMonthly Interest Rate\text{Interest Amount} = \text{Outstanding Principal} \times \text{Monthly Interest Rate}Interest Amount=Outstanding PrincipalMonthly Interest Rate
  • Repayment Schedule: Interest decreases as the principal reduces with each installment.

3. Compounding Interest

  • Formula: A=P(1+rn)ntA = P \times \left(1 + \frac{r}{n}\right)^{n \times t}A=P(1+nr)nt Where:
    • AAA: Total amount after ttt years
    • PPP: Principal amount
    • rrr: Annual interest rate
    • nnn: Number of times interest is compounded per year

Functionality

1. Loan Creation

  • User specifies loan details including interest type.
  • System calculates the total expected interest and generates a repayment schedule.

2. Repayment Tracking

  • Each payment creates a record in LoanLines and updates the remaining_amount in the Loan model.
  • For reducing balance and compounding interest, recalculate outstanding interest based on the new principal.

3. Alerts and Notifications

  • Upcoming Payment Reminder: Notify users 10 days, 5 days, and 1 day before the due date.
  • Missed Payment: If no payment is recorded by the due date:
    • Calculate a penalty using penalty_rate.
    • Add a penalty entry in LoanLines.
    • Update the loan's remaining_amount.

4. Missed Payment Calculation

  • Penalty Addition: Penalty=Remaining AmountPenalty Rate\text{Penalty} = \text{Remaining Amount} \times \text{Penalty Rate}Penalty=Remaining AmountPenalty Rate
  • Apply penalty to the outstanding balance.
  • Recalculate repayment amounts if required.

5. Loan Closure

  • Mark the loan as Paid once the remaining_amount is zero.

Integration with Transactions

  1. Payment Entry:

    • When a payment is made for a loan, create a Transaction entry.
    • Link the Transaction to the LoanLines.

  2. Penalty Entry:

    • Create a Transaction entry for the penalty and link it to the LoanLines.

  3. Adjustment Entry:

    • For manual adjustments (e.g., early repayment or waived penalties), create a Transaction entry and link it to the LoanLines.

UI Workflow

1. Loan Dashboard

  • Display active loans, their status, and repayment progress.
  • Highlight upcoming payments with alerts.

2. Loan Details

  • Show detailed information about the loan, including repayment schedule and history.
  • Provide options to make a payment or early repayment.

3. Alerts and Notifications

  • Notify users about upcoming payments, overdue amounts, and penalties.

Benefits

  1. Flexible Interest Calculation: Supports diverse interest methods.
  2. Penalty Tracking: Ensures users are aware of missed payments and their impact.
  3. Integrated Management: Links all payments and penalties seamlessly with Transactions.

To integrate the loan-related models (Loan and LoanLines) with the Transaction model, we can establish relationships and implement logic that ensures all loan payments, penalties, and adjustments are automatically reflected in the Transaction model.

Steps to Link Loan Models to the Transaction Model

1. Transaction Model

Update the Transaction model to accommodate loan-related entries.

Transaction Schema:

Column NameData TypeDescription
idbigintPrimary key
user_idbigintForeign key linking to the user who made the transaction
transaction_typestringType of transaction: Loan Payment, Penalty, etc.
amountdecimalTransaction amount
datedateDate of the transaction
loan_idbigintForeign key linking to the Loan model
descriptiontextNotes about the transaction (optional)
created_atdatetimeTimestamp of creation
updated_atdatetimeTimestamp of the last update

2. Relationships

Loan Model

ruby
class Loan < ApplicationRecord
  belongs_to :user
  has_many :loan_lines, dependent: :destroy
  has_many :transactions, through: :loan_lines
end

LoanLines Model

ruby
class LoanLine < ApplicationRecord
  belongs_to :loan
  belongs_to :transaction
end

Transaction Model

ruby
class Transaction < ApplicationRecord
  belongs_to :user
  has_one :loan_line, dependent: :destroy
  belongs_to :loan, optional: true # For loan-related transactions
end

3. Workflow Logic

Loan Payment

  • When a user makes a payment:
    1. Create a Transaction entry with transaction_type: "Loan Payment".
    2. Link the Transaction to the Loan via the LoanLines model.
    3. Update the loan's remaining_amount.

Implementation:

ruby
def create_loan_payment(loan_id, amount, user_id)
  loan = Loan.find(loan_id)
  raise "Loan not found" unless loan

  # Create the transaction
  transaction = Transaction.create!(
    user_id: user_id,
    transaction_type: "Loan Payment",
    amount: amount,
    date: Date.today,
    description: "Payment towards Loan ##{loan.id}"
  )

  # Create loan line linked to the transaction
  LoanLine.create!(
    loan_id: loan.id,
    transaction_id: transaction.id,
    entry_date: Date.today,
    amount: amount,
    type: "Payment",
    description: "Payment for Loan ##{loan.id}"
  )

  # Update loan remaining amount
  loan.remaining_amount -= amount
  loan.status = "Paid" if loan.remaining_amount <= 0
  loan.save!
end

Penalty for Missed Payment

  • When a user misses a payment:
    1. Calculate the penalty based on the outstanding balance and penalty rate.
    2. Create a Transaction entry with transaction_type: "Penalty".
    3. Link the Transaction to the Loan via the LoanLines model.
    4. Update the loan's remaining_amount.

Implementation:

ruby
def apply_penalty_for_missed_payment(loan_id, penalty_amount)
  loan = Loan.find(loan_id)
  raise "Loan not found" unless loan

  # Create the transaction
  transaction = Transaction.create!(
    user_id: loan.user_id,
    transaction_type: "Penalty",
    amount: penalty_amount,
    date: Date.today,
    description: "Penalty for missed payment on Loan ##{loan.id}"
  )

  # Create loan line linked to the transaction
  LoanLine.create!(
    loan_id: loan.id,
    transaction_id: transaction.id,
    entry_date: Date.today,
    amount: penalty_amount,
    type: "Penalty",
    description: "Missed payment penalty for Loan ##{loan.id}"
  )

  # Update loan remaining amount
  loan.remaining_amount += penalty_amount
  loan.save!
end

4. Alerts for Upcoming Payments

  • Notifications:
    • Check all loans with status: Active.
    • If the due_date is within the next 10 days, notify the user.

Implementation:

ruby
def alert_upcoming_payments
  loans = Loan.where("due_date BETWEEN ? AND ?", Date.today + 1, Date.today + 10)
  loans.each do |loan|
    # Send notification to user
    UserNotifier.send_payment_reminder(loan.user_id, loan.id, loan.due_date)
  end
end

5. Integration with Transactions

Linking Loan to Transaction

  • Every loan-related action (e.g., payment, penalty, adjustment) must create a corresponding Transaction entry.
  • Use LoanLines as a bridge between Loan and Transaction.

View Example

  • Loan Details Page: Show all linked transactions.
  • Transaction History Page: Include loan-related transactions with details.

Benefits of Integration

  1. Unified Tracking: All loan payments, penalties, and adjustments are in one place.
  2. Automation: Automated linking ensures no manual bookkeeping errors.
  3. Scalability: Adding new features like interest rate adjustments or bulk repayments is easier with this structure.

To design a comprehensive system for your personal finance project, I'll break down the models you mentioned, how they interlink with each other, and their functionalities. This includes key entities like Account, Bank, Transaction, Budget, SavingGoals, Investment, Debt, Loan, and how they interact to create a cohesive system.

System Overview

This system will allow users to manage their finances, track transactions, manage savings, handle loans and debts, create budgets, and make investments, all with real-time tracking and relationships between each entity.

1. Models and Their Functionalities

Account Model

An account represents the user's financial account, where they can store their money (bank account, wallet, etc.).

Schema:

  • id: Integer, primary key
  • user_id: Integer, Foreign key to User
  • account_type: String (Bank, Wallet, etc.)
  • balance: Decimal, current account balance
  • currency: String (USD, INR, etc.)
  • created_at: DateTime
  • updated_at: DateTime

Functionality:

  • Store users available balance.
  • Link to other financial actions like transactions (income, expenses, investments).

Bank Model

A bank represents a specific institution where a user holds one or more accounts.

Schema:

  • id: Integer, primary key
  • name: String, Bank name (e.g., Chase, Bank of America)
  • user_id: Integer, Foreign key to User
  • created_at: DateTime
  • updated_at: DateTime

Functionality:

  • Link to multiple Account models.
  • Manage accounts related to specific banks.

Transaction Model

Tracks all financial activities income, expense, loan payment, investment, debt repayments, etc. All financial actions are recorded as transactions.

Schema:

  • id: Integer, primary key
  • user_id: Integer, Foreign key to User
  • transaction_type: String (Income, Expense, Loan Payment, etc.)
  • amount: Decimal
  • description: Text (Details of the transaction)
  • date: Date
  • account_id: Integer, Foreign key to Account (Where the transaction happened)
  • related_object_type: String (Debt, Loan, Investment, etc.)
  • related_object_id: Integer (ID of related object if applicable)
  • created_at: DateTime
  • updated_at: DateTime

Functionality:

  • Record each transaction related to income, expense, debt repayment, loan payment, investment.
  • Link transactions to accounts and relevant objects (loan, debt, etc.).

Budget Model

Manages users planned monthly budget for different categories (e.g., food, entertainment, savings).

Schema:

  • id: Integer, primary key
  • user_id: Integer, Foreign key to User
  • category: String (e.g., Food, Entertainment, Savings)
  • budgeted_amount: Decimal, planned amount for the category
  • spent_amount: Decimal, amount spent in the current month
  • month: Date
  • created_at: DateTime
  • updated_at: DateTime

Functionality:

  • Set monthly budget goals for each category.
  • Track spending and alert if spending exceeds budget.

SavingGoals Model

Tracks users specific savings goals like "Emergency Fund", "Car Purchase", or "Vacation Fund".

Schema:

  • id: Integer, primary key
  • user_id: Integer, Foreign key to User
  • goal_name: String (e.g., Emergency Fund, Car Fund)
  • goal_amount: Decimal (Total goal amount to save)
  • current_savings: Decimal (Amount saved so far)
  • target_date: Date (When the goal should be achieved)
  • created_at: DateTime
  • updated_at: DateTime

Functionality:

  • Users create specific savings goals.
  • Track progress towards goals.
  • Create transactions to add to savings goals (e.g., user saving $100 per month for their car fund).

Investment Model

Represents various investment opportunities like stocks, mutual funds, SIPs, or cryptos.

Schema:

  • id: Integer, primary key
  • user_id: Integer, Foreign key to User
  • investment_type: String (e.g., Stock, Mutual Fund, Crypto)
  • investment_amount: Decimal, amount invested
  • investment_value: Decimal, current value of the investment
  • created_at: DateTime
  • updated_at: DateTime

Functionality:

  • Track various types of investments.
  • Link investments to transactions, allowing users to track the purchase and any changes in value over time.

Debt Model

Represents money the user owes to others (e.g., credit card debt, personal loans). It can be linked to specific debts like car loans, credit card repayments, etc.

Schema:

  • id: Integer, primary key
  • user_id: Integer, Foreign key to User
  • total_amount: Decimal, total debt amount
  • remaining_amount: Decimal, current debt balance
  • interest_rate: Decimal, interest rate
  • debt_type: String (e.g., Credit Card, Personal Loan)
  • created_at: DateTime
  • updated_at: DateTime

Functionality:

  • Track total and remaining debt.
  • Automatically calculate interest based on the type of debt.
  • Link debt repayment transactions to decrease the debt balance.
  • Track changes in debt as payments are made or missed.

Loan Model

Represents money the user has borrowed from others. Can include various loan types (e.g., flat interest, reducing balance, compound interest).

Schema:

  • id: Integer, primary key
  • user_id: Integer, Foreign key to User
  • loan_type: String (e.g., Personal Loan, Mortgage)
  • principal_amount: Decimal, the amount borrowed
  • interest_rate: Decimal, interest rate on the loan
  • due_date: Date, the loans due date for repayment
  • status: String (e.g., Active, Paid)
  • remaining_amount: Decimal, remaining balance to be paid
  • created_at: DateTime
  • updated_at: DateTime

Functionality:

  • Track loans with their terms and interest rates.
  • Track monthly payments, including interest and principal repayments.
  • Generate alerts for upcoming payments or missed payments.
  • Link loan payments to transactions and reduce the loan balance.

2. Relationships Between Models

  • Account & Bank: An account is linked to a specific bank. Each user can have multiple accounts, each belonging to a different bank or wallet.

  • Transaction & Account: Each transaction is linked to an account, showing which account the transaction came from or was made to. Transactions include incomes, expenses, and payments related to loans, debts, or investments.

  • Transaction & Debt/Loan/Investment: Transactions can be linked to debts, loans, or investments when a user makes a payment toward their loan, investment, or debt.

  • Transaction & Budget: Transactions are also linked to the budget, tracking spending in various categories.

  • SavingGoal & Transaction: Users can create saving goals and link them to specific transactions. Every time a user adds to a saving goal, a transaction is created to reflect that addition.

  • Debt & Loan: A debt represents money owed by the user (e.g., credit card debt), while a loan represents money borrowed by the user (e.g., personal loan, mortgage). Both debts and loans can have different types of interest calculations and repayment plans.

3. Functionality and Workflow

  1. Transactions: Every financial activity (income, expense, loan payment, debt repayment, investment, saving) will create a transaction entry that links to a specific account, and if it's related to a debt, loan, or investment, it will be linked through the related_object_type and related_object_id.

  2. Budget: Users can set monthly budgets for different categories. As transactions occur (e.g., spending on food, entertainment), the system tracks the user's spending and compares it with the budgeted amount.

  3. Debt and Loan Payments: When a user makes a debt or loan payment, a transaction is created to decrease the remaining debt or loan amount. If the user misses a payment, a penalty transaction will be created automatically.

  4. Saving Goals: Users create savings goals and assign amounts. Every time they deposit money into savings (tracked by transactions), the system updates the progress towards the goal.

  5. Investment: When users make an investment, the system records it as a transaction. Investments are tracked by type, and the system can update the value based on market performance.

  6. Alerting: The system will send notifications when payments are due (for loans, debts), when spending exceeds budgets, or when users are approaching their savings goals.

Summary

This system ensures all aspects of a user's financial life are linked from spending and saving to loans and investments. The relationships between Transaction, Account, Debt, Loan, Investment, Budget, and SavingGoals allow for real-time tracking, notifications, and calculations. The goal is to create an automated, transparent financial management system that provides accurate data at all times.

To summarize how different types of savings, debts, investments, and loans interact and communicate with each other in your financial system, here's a detailed breakdown. Each of these financial entities has its own unique model, and the transactions and calculations between them create a network of relationships.

1. Saving and Saving Goals

Types of Saving:

  • Emergency Fund: A fund to cover unexpected expenses, ideally stored in a liquid, easily accessible account.
  • Specific Savings: For particular goals like buying a car, a house, or for a vacation. These may be allocated to different accounts or sub-accounts.
  • Long-Term Savings: For retirement or future large purchases.

Saving Goal Model:

  • Saving Goals allow users to set specific financial targets (e.g., $5,000 for a car purchase).
  • Communication with Transaction Model:
    • When a user saves money, transactions are created for each deposit into the saving goal. For instance, if a user saves $100 towards their car fund, a transaction is created in the Transaction Model that records this deposit.
    • The system tracks the progress of the saving goal by checking the total balance in the goal vs. the goal amount.

Interaction with Other Models:

  • Account Model: When a user saves money, the money is transferred from their main bank account to their saving goal, reducing the available balance in the Account model.
  • Budget Model: Savings may be automatically deducted based on a monthly budget (e.g., saving 10% of income into an emergency fund).
  • Investment Model: If the user wishes to invest some of their savings, the savings can be moved into an investment model, where the saved money is used to purchase stocks, bonds, or other securities.

2. Debt and Debt Lines

Types of Debt:

  • Credit Card Debt: A revolving line of credit that the user owes based on their spending.
  • Personal Loans: A set loan amount with a fixed interest rate, to be paid over time.
  • Mortgage: A loan for purchasing property, usually with a long-term repayment schedule.

Debt Line Model:

  • Debt Line refers to the breakdown of payments or borrowings (e.g., payments to reduce credit card debt or personal loan installments).
  • Communication with Transaction Model:
    • When a user makes a debt payment (e.g., repaying credit card debt), a transaction is created that reduces the total debt balance. The system updates the debt balance and calculates any interest payments as part of the transaction.
    • Interest on debts (e.g., credit cards or personal loans) can accrue daily or monthly, which can be recorded as transactions.

Interaction with Other Models:

  • Account Model: When a debt payment is made, funds are deducted from the user's account balance (checking or savings).
  • Transaction Model: Every debt repayment or change in debt balance triggers a transaction. For example, repaying a personal loan results in a transaction linked to both the Debt and Loan models.
  • Loan Model: Some debts may have specific loan lines (e.g., installment payments for a personal loan), and they communicate through repayment schedules.
  • Budget Model: Users can set a portion of their budget for debt repayment. If users overspend, they may need to adjust their debt repayment budget.

3. Investment and Investment Lines

Types of Investment:

  • Stocks: Equities or shares in a company.
  • Mutual Funds: A pooled investment vehicle consisting of stocks, bonds, and other assets.
  • SIPs (Systematic Investment Plans): A method of investing a fixed sum regularly in mutual funds.
  • Cryptocurrency: Digital currencies like Bitcoin, Ethereum, etc.
  • Fixed Deposits (FD): A type of investment with a fixed interest rate for a specified time.

Investment Line Model:

  • Investment Line refers to individual investments made within a category (e.g., stocks purchased within an "Equity Investment" goal).
  • Communication with Transaction Model:
    • When a user invests, a transaction is created. For instance, buying stocks triggers a transaction entry to reflect the purchase.
    • If investments gain or lose value (e.g., stock prices change), the system updates the value of the investment in the model.

Interaction with Other Models:

  • Account Model: Investments are usually made from an account (checking or savings). Once a user decides to invest, funds are transferred from their account to the investment.
  • Transaction Model: Every time the user invests or sells an investment, a transaction is created. For example, selling stocks or mutual funds will reflect a transaction with gains or losses.
  • Saving Goal Model: If part of the users savings is invested (e.g., transferring $500 from an emergency fund to an investment account), the saving goal model is updated accordingly.

4. Loan Model

Types of Loans:

  • Flat Interest Loans: Interest is calculated on the entire principal amount throughout the loan term.
  • Reducing Balance Loans: Interest is calculated only on the remaining loan balance.
  • Compound Interest Loans: Interest is calculated on both the principal and any accumulated interest, compounding periodically.

Loan Line Model:

  • Loan Line refers to the breakdown of the loan amount and repayment installments (e.g., monthly repayment amounts).
  • Communication with Transaction Model:
    • When a user makes a loan payment (whether its a principal or interest payment), a transaction is created. The system will update the remaining loan balance.
    • If the user has multiple loans, each loan payment will be linked to a specific loan and payment line.

Interaction with Other Models:

  • Account Model: Loan repayments are deducted from the users bank account (checking, savings, etc.).
  • Transaction Model: Each loan payment (either principal or interest) creates a transaction entry, linking it to both the Loan and Debt models.
  • Debt Model: Loans can be considered a form of debt. Payments made on a loan will reduce the overall debt balance and interest charges.
  • Budget Model: Monthly loan repayments are included in the users budget for loan servicing.

5. Real-Time Communication Between All Models

Each of these models (savings, debts, loans, and investments) communicates in real-time based on the transactions made by the user:

  1. Transactions Trigger Updates: Whenever a user makes a payment, adds to a savings goal, or buys an investment, a new transaction entry is created. This entry triggers updates in the associated models (e.g., debt, loan, savings, investments).

  2. Balance Calculations: The system dynamically recalculates balances after each transaction. For instance, if a user repays a loan, the remaining_amount in the Loan Model decreases, and the corresponding payment is recorded as a transaction.

  3. Interest Calculations: Interest on debts or loans is dynamically calculated based on the type of loan (flat, reducing, compound). For instance:

    • Flat Interest Loan: Interest is added based on the total loan amount.
    • Reducing Loan: Interest is recalculated on the reduced principal balance.
    • Compound Interest Loan: Interest is recalculated based on the compounded amount, which includes both the principal and accumulated interest.

  4. Alerts and Notifications: The system can alert users when:

    • They exceed their budget.
    • A loan repayment is due soon.
    • A saving goal is nearing its target.
    • Investments have gained or lost value.

6. Key Workflow Example (End-to-End)

  1. User Saves Money: The user saves $100 towards their Car Fund. This is recorded in the SavingGoal model, with a transaction being created in the Transaction model.

  2. User Invests in Mutual Fund: The user decides to invest $50 from their savings in a mutual fund. A new transaction is created, reflecting the amount transferred to the Investment model, and the value of the mutual fund is updated.

  3. User Pays Loan Installment: The user makes a payment of $150 towards their personal loan. A transaction entry reduces the loan balance, and the remaining balance is recalculated.

  4. User Overspends: If the user exceeds their budget for groceries, for example, the system sends an alert. The spending is recorded in the Transaction model and checked against the Budget model.

  5. Interest Accrues on Debt: Monthly interest is calculated on any outstanding debt (e.g., credit card or personal loan). Interest charges are automatically recorded as transactions and added to the debt balance.

Conclusion

The Saving Goals, Debt, Investment, and Loan Models work together seamlessly, where transactions serve as the linking element between them. Each model communicates by adjusting balances, tracking payments, and providing alerts for any changes or due dates. By leveraging these relationships, users can maintain a holistic view of their financial situation, whether it involves savings, investments, loans, or debts.

content = """
To summarize how different types of savings, debts, investments, and loans interact and communicate with each other in your financial system, here's a detailed breakdown. Each of these financial entities has its own unique model, and the transactions and calculations between them create a network of relationships.

1. Saving and Saving Goals

Types of Saving:
- Emergency Fund: A fund to cover unexpected expenses, ideally stored in a liquid, easily accessible account.
- Specific Savings: For particular goals like buying a car, a house, or for a vacation. These may be allocated to different accounts or sub-accounts.
- Long-Term Savings: For retirement or future large purchases.

Saving Goal Model:
- Saving Goals allow users to set specific financial targets (e.g., $5,000 for a car purchase).
- Communication with Transaction Model:
  - When a user saves money, transactions are created for each deposit into the saving goal. For instance, if a user saves $100 towards their car fund, a transaction is created in the Transaction Model that records this deposit.
  - The system tracks the progress of the saving goal by checking the total balance in the goal vs. the goal amount.

Interaction with Other Models:
- Account Model: When a user saves money, the money is transferred from their main bank account to their saving goal, reducing the available balance in the Account model.
- Budget Model: Savings may be automatically deducted based on a monthly budget (e.g., saving 10% of income into an emergency fund).
- Investment Model: If the user wishes to invest some of their savings, the savings can be moved into an investment model, where the saved money is used to purchase stocks, bonds, or other securities.

2. Debt and Debt Lines

Types of Debt:
- Credit Card Debt: A revolving line of credit that the user owes based on their spending.
- Personal Loans: A set loan amount with a fixed interest rate, to be paid over time.
- Mortgage: A loan for purchasing property, usually with a long-term repayment schedule.

Debt Line Model:
- Debt Line refers to the breakdown of payments or borrowings (e.g., payments to reduce credit card debt or personal loan installments).
- Communication with Transaction Model:
  - When a user makes a debt payment (e.g., repaying credit card debt), a transaction is created that reduces the total debt balance. The system updates the debt balance and calculates any interest payments as part of the transaction.
  - Interest on debts (e.g., credit cards or personal loans) can accrue daily or monthly, which can be recorded as transactions.

Interaction with Other Models:
- Account Model: When a debt payment is made, funds are deducted from the user's account balance (checking or savings).
- Transaction Model: Every debt repayment or change in debt balance triggers a transaction. For example, repaying a personal loan results in a transaction linked to both the Debt and Loan models.
- Loan Model: Some debts may have specific loan lines (e.g., installment payments for a personal loan), and they communicate through repayment schedules.
- Budget Model: Users can set a portion of their budget for debt repayment. If users overspend, they may need to adjust their debt repayment budget.

3. Investment and Investment Lines

Types of Investment:
- Stocks: Equities or shares in a company.
- Mutual Funds: A pooled investment vehicle consisting of stocks, bonds, and other assets.
- SIPs (Systematic Investment Plans): A method of investing a fixed sum regularly in mutual funds.
- Cryptocurrency: Digital currencies like Bitcoin, Ethereum, etc.
- Fixed Deposits (FD): A type of investment with a fixed interest rate for a specified time.

Investment Line Model:
- Investment Line refers to individual investments made within a category (e.g., stocks purchased within an "Equity Investment" goal).
- Communication with Transaction Model:
  - When a user invests, a transaction is created. For instance, buying stocks triggers a transaction entry to reflect the purchase.
  - If investments gain or lose value (e.g., stock prices change), the system updates the value of the investment in the model.

Interaction with Other Models:
- Account Model: Investments are usually made from an account (checking or savings). Once a user decides to invest, funds are transferred from their account to the investment.
- Transaction Model: Every time the user invests or sells an investment, a transaction is created. For example, selling stocks or mutual funds will reflect a transaction with gains or losses.
- Saving Goal Model: If part of the users savings is invested (e.g., transferring $500 from an emergency fund to an investment account), the saving goal model is updated accordingly.

4. Loan Model

Types of Loans:
- Flat Interest Loans: Interest is calculated on the entire principal amount throughout the loan term.
- Reducing Balance Loans: Interest is calculated only on the remaining loan balance.
- Compound Interest Loans: Interest is calculated on both the principal and any accumulated interest, compounding periodically.

Loan Line Model:
- Loan Line refers to the breakdown of the loan amount and repayment installments (e.g., monthly repayment amounts).
- Communication with Transaction Model:
  - When a user makes a loan payment (whether its a principal or interest payment), a transaction is created. The system will update the remaining loan balance.
  - If the user has multiple loans, each loan payment will be linked to a specific loan and payment line.

Interaction with Other Models:
- Account Model: Loan repayments are deducted from the users bank account (checking, savings, etc.).
- Transaction Model: Each loan payment (either principal or interest) creates a transaction entry, linking it to both the Loan and Debt models.
- Debt Model: Loans can be considered a form of debt. Payments made on a loan will reduce the overall debt balance and interest charges.
- Budget Model: Monthly loan repayments are included in the users budget for loan servicing.

5. Real-Time Communication Between All Models

Each of these models (savings, debts, loans, and investments) communicates in real-time based on the transactions made by the user:

1. Transactions Trigger Updates: Whenever a user makes a payment, adds to a savings goal, or buys an investment, a new transaction entry is created. This entry triggers updates in the associated models (e.g., debt, loan, savings, investments).

2. Balance Calculations: The system dynamically recalculates balances after each transaction. For instance, if a user repays a loan, the remaining_amount in the Loan Model decreases, and the corresponding payment is recorded as a transaction.

3. Interest Calculations: Interest on debts or loans is dynamically calculated based on the type of loan (flat, reducing, compound). For instance:
   - Flat Interest Loan: Interest is added based on the total loan amount.
   - Reducing Loan: Interest is recalculated on the reduced principal balance.
   - Compound Interest Loan: Interest is recalculated based on the compounded amount, which includes both the principal and accumulated interest.

4. Alerts and Notifications: The system can alert users when:
   - They exceed their budget.
   - A loan repayment is due soon.
   - A saving goal is nearing its target.
   - Investments have gained or lost value.

6. Key Workflow Example (End-to-End)

1. User Saves Money: The user saves $100 towards their Car Fund. This is recorded in the SavingGoal model, with a transaction being created in the Transaction model.

2. User Invests in Mutual Fund: The user decides to invest $50 from their savings in a mutual fund. A new transaction is created, reflecting the amount transferred to the Investment model, and the value of the mutual fund is updated.

3. User Pays Loan Installment: The user makes a payment of $150 towards their personal loan. A transaction entry reduces the loan balance, and the remaining balance is recalculated.

4. User Overspends: If the user exceeds their budget for groceries, for example, the system sends an alert. The spending is recorded in the Transaction model and checked against the Budget model.

5. Interest Accrues on Debt: Monthly interest is calculated on any outstanding debt (e.g., credit card or personal loan). Interest charges are automatically recorded as transactions and added to the debt balance.

Conclusion

The Saving Goals, Debt, Investment, and Loan Models work together seamlessly, where transactions serve as the linking element between them. Each model communicates by adjusting balances, tracking payments, and providing alerts for any changes or due dates. By leveraging these relationships, users can maintain a holistic view of their financial situation, whether it involves savings, investments, loans, or debts.

tell me how my table look like give schema for all model
ChatGPT said:

Here is a schema outline for your financial models based on the various entities you've described (Saving, Debt, Investment, Loan). Each table will store specific information relevant to its function, and their relationships will be handled through foreign keys or linked attributes.

1. Saving Goal Model (saving_goals table)

This table will store information related to each of the saving goals.

sql
CREATE TABLE saving_goals (
    id SERIAL PRIMARY KEY,
    user_id INT NOT NULL,  -- Foreign Key to users table
    goal_name VARCHAR(255),
    target_amount DECIMAL(15, 2),
    current_balance DECIMAL(15, 2) DEFAULT 0.00,
    start_date DATE,
    end_date DATE,
    created_at TIMESTAMP DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP,
    updated_at TIMESTAMP DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP,
    FOREIGN KEY (user_id) REFERENCES users(id) -- Assuming a users table exists
);

2. Transaction Model (transactions table)

This table tracks each transaction (deposit, withdrawal, payment, etc.).

sql
CREATE TABLE transactions (
    id SERIAL PRIMARY KEY,
    user_id INT NOT NULL,  -- Foreign Key to users table
    transaction_type VARCHAR(255),  -- 'Deposit', 'Withdrawal', 'Transfer', 'Investment', etc.
    amount DECIMAL(15, 2),
    transaction_date TIMESTAMP DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP,
    description TEXT,
    saving_goal_id INT,  -- Optional Foreign Key to saving_goals
    debt_id INT,  -- Optional Foreign Key to debts
    loan_id INT,  -- Optional Foreign Key to loans
    investment_id INT,  -- Optional Foreign Key to investments
    FOREIGN KEY (user_id) REFERENCES users(id),
    FOREIGN KEY (saving_goal_id) REFERENCES saving_goals(id),
    FOREIGN KEY (debt_id) REFERENCES debts(id),
    FOREIGN KEY (loan_id) REFERENCES loans(id),
    FOREIGN KEY (investment_id) REFERENCES investments(id)
);

3. Debt Model (debts table)

This table stores information related to the user's debts, such as credit card debt or personal loans.

sql
CREATE TABLE debts (
    id SERIAL PRIMARY KEY,
    user_id INT NOT NULL,  -- Foreign Key to users table
    debt_type VARCHAR(255),  -- 'Credit Card', 'Personal Loan', etc.
    principal_amount DECIMAL(15, 2),
    remaining_balance DECIMAL(15, 2),
    interest_rate DECIMAL(5, 2),
    due_date DATE,
    created_at TIMESTAMP DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP,
    updated_at TIMESTAMP DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP,
    FOREIGN KEY (user_id) REFERENCES users(id)
);

4. Investment Model (investments table)

This table stores information about each investment (stocks, mutual funds, cryptocurrencies, etc.).

sql
CREATE TABLE investments (
    id SERIAL PRIMARY KEY,
    user_id INT NOT NULL,  -- Foreign Key to users table
    investment_type VARCHAR(255),  -- 'Stock', 'Mutual Fund', 'Crypto', etc.
    invested_amount DECIMAL(15, 2),
    current_value DECIMAL(15, 2),
    purchase_date DATE,
    created_at TIMESTAMP DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP,
    updated_at TIMESTAMP DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP,
    FOREIGN KEY (user_id) REFERENCES users(id)
);

5. Loan Model (loans table)

This table tracks loans taken by users, such as home loans, personal loans, etc.

sql
CREATE TABLE loans (
    id SERIAL PRIMARY KEY,
    user_id INT NOT NULL,  -- Foreign Key to users table
    loan_type VARCHAR(255),  -- 'Home Loan', 'Personal Loan', etc.
    loan_amount DECIMAL(15, 2),
    remaining_balance DECIMAL(15, 2),
    interest_rate DECIMAL(5, 2),
    repayment_schedule TEXT,  -- 'Monthly', 'Bi-weekly', etc.
    created_at TIMESTAMP DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP,
    updated_at TIMESTAMP DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP,
    FOREIGN KEY (user_id) REFERENCES users(id)
);

6. User Table (users table)

To support the foreign key references in the other tables, you'll need a users table, which stores basic user information.

sql
CREATE TABLE users (
    id SERIAL PRIMARY KEY,
    name VARCHAR(255),
    email VARCHAR(255) UNIQUE,
    password_hash VARCHAR(255),
    created_at TIMESTAMP DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP,
    updated_at TIMESTAMP DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP
);

7. Budget Model (budgets table)

This table will store the user's budget breakdown, allowing for budgeted amounts to be tracked.

sql
CREATE TABLE budgets (
    id SERIAL PRIMARY KEY,
    user_id INT NOT NULL,  -- Foreign Key to users table
    category VARCHAR(255),  -- 'Groceries', 'Utilities', 'Entertainment', etc.
    allocated_amount DECIMAL(15, 2),
    spent_amount DECIMAL(15, 2) DEFAULT 0.00,
    month DATE,  -- Month and Year for the budget
    created_at TIMESTAMP DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP,
    updated_at TIMESTAMP DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP,
    FOREIGN KEY (user_id) REFERENCES users(id)
);

Relationships and Interactions Between Models

  1. User-to-Goal Relationship: Each user can have multiple saving goals (user_id in saving_goals table), and each goal may have associated transactions (deposits or withdrawals).

  2. Transaction-to-Multiple Models: Transactions can be associated with different models (debt, loan, investment, or saving goal) through the foreign key relationships in the transactions table.

  3. Debt-to-Transaction Relationship: Debt repayments will be stored in the transactions table with links to the appropriate debt model.

  4. Loan-to-Transaction Relationship: Loan repayments will also be tracked in the transactions table with links to the loan model.

  5. Budget-to-Transaction Relationship: The budget model will track allocated and spent amounts. You can compare transactions to see how they fit within the budgeted categories.

This schema setup enables you to track all the interactions between savings, debts, investments, and loans within a users financial system, with clear communication between the models through the transactions table.

You said:
how to look like my lines for debt, goals, investment, loans and they connected with transactions
ChatGPT said:

To track and manage "lines" for debt, goals, investments, and loans, we need separate tables for each of them. These lines represent specific details or entries (like payments, changes in goals, partial investments, etc.) that are linked to the main entity (debt, goal, investment, or loan). Each line entry can then be connected to a transaction to track when and how these changes occurred.

Lets break it down by each model, including the lines and their connection to the transactions table.

1. Debt Lines (debt_lines table)

Debt lines track individual payments or changes made toward a specific debt. Each line can represent a repayment or interest adjustment.

sql
CREATE TABLE debt_lines (
    id SERIAL PRIMARY KEY,
    debt_id INT NOT NULL,  -- Foreign Key to debts table
    amount DECIMAL(15, 2),  -- Amount paid or interest added
    transaction_id INT,  -- Foreign Key to transactions table
    payment_date TIMESTAMP DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP,
    transaction_type VARCHAR(255),  -- 'Repayment', 'Interest', etc.
    created_at TIMESTAMP DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP,
    updated_at TIMESTAMP DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP,
    FOREIGN KEY (debt_id) REFERENCES debts(id),
    FOREIGN KEY (transaction_id) REFERENCES transactions(id)
);

Explanation:

  • debt_id: Links this line entry to the specific debt.
  • amount: Tracks the amount involved in the transaction (whether it's repayment or interest).
  • transaction_id: Links the transaction in the transactions table that created or modified this debt line.

2. Goal Lines (goal_lines table)

Goal lines track each action (deposit, withdrawal, adjustment) made toward a specific saving goal.

sql
CREATE TABLE goal_lines (
    id SERIAL PRIMARY KEY,
    saving_goal_id INT NOT NULL,  -- Foreign Key to saving_goals table
    amount DECIMAL(15, 2),  -- Amount saved or withdrawn
    transaction_id INT,  -- Foreign Key to transactions table
    action_type VARCHAR(255),  -- 'Deposit', 'Withdrawal', etc.
    created_at TIMESTAMP DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP,
    updated_at TIMESTAMP DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP,
    FOREIGN KEY (saving_goal_id) REFERENCES saving_goals(id),
    FOREIGN KEY (transaction_id) REFERENCES transactions(id)
);

Explanation:

  • saving_goal_id: Links this line entry to the specific saving goal.
  • amount: Tracks the amount saved or withdrawn.
  • transaction_id: Links the transaction that created or modified this goal line.

3. Investment Lines (investment_lines table)

Investment lines represent individual changes to an investment (like adding money, withdrawing, or changes in its value).

sql
CREATE TABLE investment_lines (
    id SERIAL PRIMARY KEY,
    investment_id INT NOT NULL,  -- Foreign Key to investments table
    amount DECIMAL(15, 2),  -- Amount invested or withdrawn
    transaction_id INT,  -- Foreign Key to transactions table
    change_type VARCHAR(255),  -- 'Investment', 'Withdrawal', 'Value Change', etc.
    created_at TIMESTAMP DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP,
    updated_at TIMESTAMP DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP,
    FOREIGN KEY (investment_id) REFERENCES investments(id),
    FOREIGN KEY (transaction_id) REFERENCES transactions(id)
);

Explanation:

  • investment_id: Links this line entry to the specific investment.
  • amount: Tracks the amount invested or withdrawn.
  • transaction_id: Links the transaction that created or modified this investment line.

4. Loan Lines (loan_lines table)

Loan lines track repayments or any adjustments to the loan amount.

sql
CREATE TABLE loan_lines (
    id SERIAL PRIMARY KEY,
    loan_id INT NOT NULL,  -- Foreign Key to loans table
    amount DECIMAL(15, 2),  -- Amount repaid or adjusted
    transaction_id INT,  -- Foreign Key to transactions table
    repayment_date TIMESTAMP DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP,
    action_type VARCHAR(255),  -- 'Repayment', 'Prepayment', 'Interest', etc.
    created_at TIMESTAMP DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP,
    updated_at TIMESTAMP DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP,
    FOREIGN KEY (loan_id) REFERENCES loans(id),
    FOREIGN KEY (transaction_id) REFERENCES transactions(id)
);

Explanation:

  • loan_id: Links this line entry to the specific loan.
  • amount: Tracks the amount repaid or interest added.
  • transaction_id: Links the transaction that created or modified this loan line.

5. Transactions Table (transactions table)

The transactions table remains the central place for recording all types of activities, including those affecting debt, goals, investments, and loans.

sql
CREATE TABLE transactions (
    id SERIAL PRIMARY KEY,
    user_id INT NOT NULL,  -- Foreign Key to users table
    transaction_type VARCHAR(255),  -- 'Deposit', 'Withdrawal', 'Transfer', 'Investment', 'Repayment', etc.
    amount DECIMAL(15, 2),
    transaction_date TIMESTAMP DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP,
    description TEXT,
    saving_goal_id INT,  -- Optional Foreign Key to saving_goals
    debt_id INT,  -- Optional Foreign Key to debts
    loan_id INT,  -- Optional Foreign Key to loans
    investment_id INT,  -- Optional Foreign Key to investments
    FOREIGN KEY (user_id) REFERENCES users(id),
    FOREIGN KEY (saving_goal_id) REFERENCES saving_goals(id),
    FOREIGN KEY (debt_id) REFERENCES debts(id),
    FOREIGN KEY (loan_id) REFERENCES loans(id),
    FOREIGN KEY (investment_id) REFERENCES investments(id)
);

How They Connect:

  1. Transactions Table:

    • Every transaction can impact debt, saving goals, loans, or investments, so the transactions table contains foreign keys (debt_id, saving_goal_id, loan_id, investment_id) to the respective models.
    • The transaction_type describes whether the transaction is a repayment, deposit, withdrawal, etc.
    • Each transaction can create or update a line in the related table (debt_lines, goal_lines, loan_lines, investment_lines).

  2. Debt Lines:

    • When a repayment is made toward a debt, a new entry is added to the debt_lines table, linking to the corresponding debt and transaction.

  3. Goal Lines:

    • Each deposit or withdrawal from a saving goal is logged in the goal_lines table, linking to the corresponding saving_goal and transaction.

  4. Investment Lines:

    • Changes in the value or contributions to an investment are recorded in the investment_lines table, linked to the investment and transaction.

  5. Loan Lines:

    • Loan repayments, interest, or prepayments are recorded in the loan_lines table, linked to the loan and transaction.

Example Flow:

  1. Create a Transaction:

    • A user repays $100 of debt.
    • A new transaction is created in the transactions table:
      • transaction_type = 'Repayment'
      • amount = 100
      • debt_id references the specific debt.
    • A corresponding entry is created in the debt_lines table:
      • debt_id links to the same debt.
      • amount = 100
      • transaction_id links back to the transaction.

  2. Create a Saving Goal:

    • A user deposits $200 into their car fund goal.
    • A new transaction is created in the transactions table:
      • transaction_type = 'Deposit'
      • amount = 200
      • saving_goal_id references the car fund goal.
    • A new line is created in the goal_lines table:
      • saving_goal_id links to the car fund goal.
      • amount = 200
      • transaction_id links back to the transaction.

  3. Create an Investment:

    • A user invests $500 in a mutual fund.
    • A new transaction is created in the transactions table:
      • transaction_type = 'Investment'
      • amount = 500
      • investment_id references the mutual fund investment.
    • A new line is created in the investment_lines table:
      • investment_id links to the mutual fund.
      • amount = 500
      • transaction_id links back to the transaction.

By using these line tables (debt_lines, goal_lines, investment_lines, loan_lines), you ensure that each action impacting your financial records is tracked and that the transaction history is clear and consistent.

Heres a summarized overview of the system and how each model (Account, Bank, Transaction, Budget, Saving Goals, Investment, Debt, Loan, etc.) and their corresponding lines (Debt Lines, Goal Lines, Loan Lines, Investment Lines) interact in your personal finance management system.

1. Transactions Model

  • Purpose: Serves as the central table for recording all actions related to savings, debt repayments, investments, loans, etc.
  • Key Attributes:
    • user_id: Identifies the user making the transaction.
    • transaction_type: Specifies the type of transaction (e.g., 'Deposit', 'Withdrawal', 'Repayment', etc.).
    • amount: The monetary value of the transaction.
    • transaction_date: The date and time of the transaction.
    • Foreign keys to other models (e.g., debt_id, saving_goal_id, loan_id, investment_id) based on the type of transaction.

2. Debt Model & Debt Lines

  • Purpose: Tracks any borrowed amount, including the loan principal and interest, and stores the repayment history.
  • Debt Lines: Represent individual payments or interest adjustments made towards a debt.
    • Debt Lines Table:
      • debt_id: Links the line entry to the specific debt.
      • amount: The amount repaid or adjusted (could include interest).
      • transaction_id: Links to the corresponding transaction.
      • payment_date: The date when the debt repayment was made.
  • Interaction: When a user makes a debt repayment, a corresponding entry is created in both the transactions table and the debt_lines table.

3. Saving Goals Model & Goal Lines

  • Purpose: Tracks user-defined saving goals (e.g., emergency fund, car fund, etc.) and monitors progress.
  • Goal Lines: Represent actions towards achieving a saving goal (e.g., deposits, withdrawals, adjustments).
    • Goal Lines Table:
      • saving_goal_id: Links the line entry to a specific goal.
      • amount: The amount saved or withdrawn from the goal.
      • transaction_id: Links to the corresponding transaction.
      • action_type: Describes the action (e.g., 'Deposit', 'Withdrawal').
  • Interaction: When a user deposits or withdraws from a goal, a corresponding entry is created in both the transactions and goal_lines tables.

4. Investment Model & Investment Lines

  • Purpose: Tracks investments such as stocks, mutual funds, SIPs, crypto, etc.
  • Investment Lines: Represent actions related to an investment, such as adding funds, withdrawing, or changes in value.
    • Investment Lines Table:
      • investment_id: Links the line entry to a specific investment.
      • amount: The amount invested or withdrawn.
      • transaction_id: Links to the corresponding transaction.
      • change_type: Describes the change (e.g., 'Investment', 'Withdrawal', 'Value Change').
  • Interaction: When a user invests or withdraws funds, a corresponding entry is created in both the transactions and investment_lines tables.

5. Loan Model & Loan Lines

  • Purpose: Tracks loans taken by the user and the repayments made towards the loan, including any interest calculations.
  • Loan Lines: Represent individual payments or interest added to a loan.
    • Loan Lines Table:
      • loan_id: Links the line entry to a specific loan.
      • amount: The amount repaid or adjusted.
      • transaction_id: Links to the corresponding transaction.
      • repayment_date: The date of the repayment.
  • Interaction: When a user repays a loan, a corresponding entry is created in both the transactions and loan_lines tables.

6. Account Model (Optional)

  • Purpose: Manages the user's bank account or wallet, tracking balances and all incoming/outgoing funds.
  • Interaction: Transactions update the balance in the users account. The transactions table links directly to the account model for balance management (e.g., deposits, withdrawals).

7. Budget Model

  • Purpose: Allows the user to set a budget and track spending in categories (e.g., Food, Rent, Entertainment).
  • Interaction: Transactions related to specific categories update the budget model. If a user spends more than their budget in a category, the system can alert them.

8. Monthly Saving & Overspend Tracking

  • Purpose: Tracks savings and alerts the user when they overspend, recalculating goals and balances accordingly.
  • Interaction:
    • At the end of the month, if there is remaining money in the user's account, they are prompted to allocate the savings toward different goals (e.g., $40 for the car fund, $10 for the emergency fund).
    • If the user overspends during the month, the system adjusts the goals and alerts the user.
    • The progress of each goal (e.g., car fund, emergency fund) is calculated and updated accordingly.

Real-Time Updates & Alerts:

  • Debt Repayment: If a user misses a repayment, the system calculates penalties or interest and alerts the user.
  • Saving Goal: If a user doesnt meet their saving goal, the system will notify them and adjust the goal progress.
  • Investment Performance: For investments, the system monitors real-time value changes (via API integration for stock or crypto), updating users on any gains or losses.

Example Scenario:

  1. User Saves Money:

    • At the end of the month, the user has $50 left and allocates $40 to their car saving goal and $10 to their emergency fund.
    • The system records this in the transactions table as a deposit and updates the goal_lines table accordingly.

  2. User Repays Debt:

    • The user repays $100 toward a debt.
    • The system records this repayment in the transactions table, creating an entry in the debt_lines table for the repayment.

  3. User Invests:

    • The user invests $200 in a mutual fund.
    • A transaction is created in the transactions table, linking the amount to the investment_lines table for future updates.

  4. User Makes Payment for Loan:

    • The user repays a loan of $150.
    • The system creates a transaction in the transactions table, and an entry is made in the loan_lines table for this repayment.

Summary of Key Interactions:

  1. Transactions Table:

    • Central point of record for all actions related to debts, savings, investments, and loans.
    • Links to specific models (debt, saving goals, loans, investments) via foreign keys.

  2. Debt Lines:

    • Track individual repayments or interest changes for debts.

  3. Goal Lines:

    • Track deposits, withdrawals, or progress towards saving goals.

  4. Investment Lines:

    • Track investments, withdrawals, and value changes for each investment.

  5. Loan Lines:

    • Track repayments and adjustments made to loans.

Each of these entities communicates with the transactions table, which allows for a centralized view of all financial activities, with line tables providing specific details for actions affecting each model (debt, goal, investment, loan). This structure allows for full tracking and visibility of every financial movement in your system.

Srs Credit Card Roles

Software Requirement Specification (SRS) for Personal Finance Management System with Credit Card Integration

1. Introduction

1.1 Purpose

The purpose of this document is to outline the requirements for a Personal Finance Management System (PFMS) that integrates functionality for managing credit cards alongside features for saving goals, investments, debts, loans, and transactions. This system will help users organize their financial activities, track expenses, and manage repayments for credit card bills.

1.2 Scope

The PFMS provides users with tools to:

  • Manage accounts, banks, and credit card payments.

  • Set saving goals and track their progress.

  • Manage debts and loans with repayment schedules.

  • Track investments in various asset classes.

  • Automatically generate credit card bills and handle payments.

  • Alert users of due dates and missed payments.

  • Provide a role-based user system for administrators, standard users, and financial advisors.

1.3 Users and Roles

  • Admin: Full access to manage users, configure system settings, and oversee all financial activities.

  • User: Access to personal financial data, transactions, saving goals, and credit card management.

  • Financial Advisor: Read-only access to user accounts for offering suggestions and analytics.

2. Functional Requirements

2.1 Credit Card Management

  1. Credit Card Information: Users can add details of their credit cards, including:

    • Card name

    • Bank

    • Card limit

    • Billing cycle start date

    • Billing cycle duration

    • Due date duration (e.g., 10 days after the billing cycle ends)

  2. Bill Generation:

    • Automatically generate a monthly bill based on transactions associated with the credit card during the billing cycle.

    • Add late fees if the due date is missed.

  3. Payments:

    • Users can pay bills partially or fully.

    • Record payments in the transaction model and update credit card balances.

  4. Notifications:

    • Notify users about upcoming due dates starting 10 days before the due date.

    • Send alerts for missed payments.

2.2 Integration with Transactions

  • Each credit card transaction links to the transactions table.

  • Payments made toward the credit card are logged in transactions with corresponding updates to the credit_card_lines table.

2.3 Roles and Permissions

Admin:

  • Manage users and roles.

  • Oversee credit card activities and handle disputes.

  • Configure notifications and system settings.

User:

  • Add, edit, and delete credit card details.

  • View and pay bills.

  • Receive notifications and alerts.

Financial Advisor:

  • View user credit card usage for advisory purposes.

2.4 Credit Card Lines

  • Store individual transactions tied to a credit card, including purchases, refunds, and payments.

  • Update the main credit_card table with the total outstanding balance.

3. Database Schema

3.1 Tables

credit_cards

ColumnTypeDescription
idUUIDPrimary key
user_idUUIDForeign key referencing users
card_nameStringName of the credit card
bank_nameStringIssuing bank name
card_limitDecimalMaximum card limit
billing_start_dateDateStart date of the billing cycle
billing_durationIntegerDuration of the billing cycle in days
due_date_durationIntegerNumber of days until the due date
current_balanceDecimalCurrent outstanding balance
created_atTimestampCreation timestamp
updated_atTimestampLast updated timestamp

credit_card_lines

ColumnTypeDescription
idUUIDPrimary key
credit_card_idUUIDForeign key referencing credit_cards
transaction_idUUIDForeign key referencing transactions
amountDecimalTransaction amount
descriptionStringDescription of the transaction
created_atTimestampCreation timestamp
updated_atTimestampLast updated timestamp

transactions

ColumnTypeDescription
idUUIDPrimary key
user_idUUIDForeign key referencing users
category_idUUIDForeign key referencing categories
amountDecimalAmount of the transaction
descriptionStringBrief description of the transaction
transaction_typeEnum'income', 'expense', 'payment', 'saving'
created_atTimestampCreation timestamp
updated_atTimestampLast updated timestamp

Relationships

  • credit_cards -> credit_card_lines: One-to-Many

  • credit_card_lines -> transactions: One-to-One

  • transactions -> users: Many-to-One

4. System Workflow

4.1 Credit Card Bill Generation

  1. User performs transactions linked to their credit card.

  2. At the end of the billing cycle:

    • Calculate the total amount due.

    • Generate a bill entry in credit_card_lines.

    • Notify the user of the total amount due and the due date.

4.2 Payment Workflow

  1. User initiates a payment for their credit card.

  2. Create a transaction entry with transaction_type as 'payment'.

  3. Update the credit_cards table's current_balance.

  4. Log the payment in credit_card_lines.

4.3 Overdue Workflow

  1. Monitor due dates and alert users starting 10 days before the due date.

  2. Apply penalties for overdue payments and update transactions and credit_card_lines.

5. Roles and Responsibilities

Admin

  • Manage all credit card entries.

  • Configure and monitor system notifications.

User

  • View and manage their credit cards and bills.

  • Perform credit card transactions and payments.

Financial Advisor

  • Provide guidance based on user credit card usage.

6. Conclusion

This system ensures comprehensive management of credit card activities, integrating seamlessly with the transactions model to provide a unified view of a user's financial activities. The modular design enables easy expansion to include additional financial tools and features in the future.

Personal Finance Srs

Software Requirements Specification (SRS)

Personal Finance Management Application

1. Introduction

The Personal Finance Management Application is designed to provide users with comprehensive tools for managing their financial activities, including income, expenses, savings, investments, debts, loans, budgets, and credit cards. The application ensures seamless integration across these components, enabling users to maintain a holistic view of their finances.

2. Goals and Objectives

  1. Financial Overview: Provide a clear view of income, expenses, savings, and investments.

  2. Automation: Automate transactions related to recurring payments, savings allocations, and investment updates.

  3. Debt and Loan Management: Enable efficient tracking and repayment of debts and loans with interest calculation.

  4. Savings Goals: Help users set, track, and achieve savings goals.

  5. Credit Card Management: Generate monthly credit card bills, set due dates, and track payments.

  6. User Roles and Permissions: Define distinct functionalities based on user roles (Admin, Regular User).

3. User Roles and Functionalities

3.1. Admin

  • Role Management:

    • Add, edit, or delete user accounts.

    • Assign roles and permissions.

  • System Monitoring:

    • Oversee transactions, loans, and investments.

    • Generate detailed financial reports.

  • Credit Card Management:

    • Set global rules for bill generation and late fees.

3.2. Regular User

  • Account Management:

    • Link multiple bank accounts.

    • Manage credit card details.

  • Transactions:

    • Add, view, and categorize transactions (income, expenses, etc.).

    • Automatically create related entries in debts, loans, and investments.

  • Savings:

    • Define savings goals with target amounts and timelines.

    • Allocate leftover monthly funds towards goals.

    • Track progress and reallocate savings if needed.

  • Debt and Loan Management:

    • Track borrowings and lendings with interest.

    • Pay debts or loans and auto-update transactions.

    • Receive warnings for missed or upcoming payments.

  • Investments:

    • Add and track real-time investments (stocks, mutual funds, SIPs, crypto, etc.).

    • View returns and portfolio performance.

  • Budgeting:

    • Set monthly budgets for categories.

    • Receive alerts for overspending.

  • Credit Card Management:

    • View monthly statements.

    • Receive alerts for bill generation and due dates.

    • Make payments and link them to transactions.

4. Functional Requirements

4.1. Account Management

  • Users can link and manage bank accounts.

  • Physical and virtual savings accounts are managed within the app.

4.2. Transaction Model

  • Every financial activity is tied to a transaction.

  • Transactions auto-generate related entries for:

    • Debts (lend/borrow money).

    • Loans (installments or repayments).

    • Investments (buy/sell activities).

    • Savings Goals (monthly allocation).

4.3. Debts

  • Main debt table links to debt lines (detailed payments or additions).

  • Interest types: flat, reduced, or compounding.

  • Alerts for missed payments and recalculations.

4.4. Loans

  • Multiple types: flat interest, reduced balance, compounding.

  • Loan lines track installments or lump-sum payments.

  • Due date alerts and missed payment adjustments.

4.5. Savings Goals

  • Users can allocate funds to multiple goals.

  • Progress is auto-updated based on transactions.

  • Negative savings balance for overspending.

4.6. Investments

  • Real-time data integration via APIs (stocks, crypto, etc.).

  • Investment lines track buy/sell activities.

  • Portfolio analysis and performance tracking.

4.7. Credit Card Management

  • Monthly bill generation for linked credit cards.

  • Tracks payments and late fees.

  • Auto-links payments to transactions.

4.8. Budgeting

  • Users can define budgets for expense categories.

  • Alerts for overspending.
